skill.name: hypothesis-generation
skill.description: Generate testable hypotheses. Formulate from observations, design experiments, explore competing explanations, develop predictions, propose mechanisms, for scientific inquiry across domains.

skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation and methodology skill with no executable code. Contains only markdown guides, LaTeX templates, and reference documents for scientific hypothesis generation. Uses only standard Claude tools (Read, Write, Edit, WebSearch, WebFetch) for literature research.

content.value_statement: Researchers struggle to develop rigorous testable hypotheses grounded in evidence. This skill provides a systematic 8-step workflow to formulate mechanistic hypotheses, design discriminating experiments, and create professional LaTeX reports.
actual_capabilities: Generate 3-5 competing mechanistic hypotheses from observations
Evaluate hypotheses against quality criteria (testability, falsifiability, parsimony)
Design experiments to test and distinguish between hypotheses
Create publication-ready LaTeX hypothesis reports with colored boxes
Search PubMed and web for relevant scientific literature
Synthesize evidence supporting and challenging each hypothesis
limitations: Does not provide domain-specific scientific expertise
Cannot perform actual experiments or access physical systems
Relies on publicly available online literature
Generated hypotheses require validation by subject matter experts

use_cases.title: A-B Testing Hypotheses
use_cases.description: Formulate and test hypotheses about product metrics and user behavior patterns

prompt_templates.title: Basic Hypothesis
prompt_templates.prompt: I observed that [phenomenon description]. Apply the hypothesis generation skill to develop 3-5 mechanistic hypotheses. Include literature search, quality evaluation, and experimental designs.

prompt_templates.title: Mechanism Investigation
prompt_templates.prompt: Investigate the mechanism of [biological process]. Search PubMed for relevant literature. Generate competing hypotheses, evaluate each against testability and falsifiability criteria, and propose discriminating experiments.

prompt_templates.title: Clinical Research
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a hypothesis-driven study to test whether [treatment] affects [outcome] in [population]. Include multiple hypotheses about the mechanism, predictions for each, and priority experiments.

prompt_templates.title: Replication Study
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to test the claim that [specific claim from literature]. Generate alternative explanations for the observations, design experiments to distinguish between hypotheses, and create a LaTeX report with the hypothesis framework.

output_examples.input: I noticed that plants near WiFi routers grow differently than plants away from routers. Help me develop scientific hypotheses to test this.
output: **Hypothesis 1:** Radiofrequency electromagnetic fields (RF-EMF) from WiFi devices alter plant growth through thermal effects on cellular processes. Predicted: RF exposure will cause measurable changes in growth rate proportional to signal strength.

**Hypothesis 2:** Electromagnetic interference affects calcium ion signaling in plant cells, disrupting growth regulation. Predicted: Adding calcium supplementation will rescue the growth phenotype under RF exposure.
**Priority Experiment:** Controlled growth chamber study with RF-shielded controls to isolate EMF effects from other environmental variables.

best_practices: Ground all hypotheses in existing literature through systematic search before generating mechanisms
Ensure each hypothesis is genuinely distinguishable from others through specific predictions
Include falsification criteria for every prediction before conducting experiments
anti_patterns: Developing hypotheses without searching existing literature first
Proposing unfalsifiable or vague hypotheses without testable predictions
Failing to seek contradicting evidence and alternative explanations

faq.question: Which AI platforms support this skill?
faq.answer: Compatible with Claude and Claude Code. The skill uses Read, Write, Edit, and Bash tools along with WebFetch and WebSearch for literature research.

faq.question: What is the maximum number of hypotheses generated?
faq.answer: The skill generates 3-5 competing hypotheses. More than 5 becomes unwieldy for distinguishing experiments. Each hypothesis must be mechanistically distinct.

faq.question: Can this skill integrate with reference managers?
faq.answer: Yes. The LaTeX template outputs BibTeX-compatible references. You can export from tools like Zotero, Mendeley, or EndNote to a .bib file.

faq.question: Is my research data handled securely?
faq.answer: The skill processes only the information you provide during the session. No data is stored or transmitted externally beyond Claude's standard security model.

faq.question: Why are my hypotheses being rejected?
faq.answer: Common issues include: hypotheses lack mechanistic explanation, no testable predictions provided, or hypotheses are not distinguishable from each other. Review the quality criteria in the skill documentation.

faq.question: How does this differ from other research skills?
faq.answer: This skill focuses specifically on hypothesis generation and experimental design. It does not perform data analysis, statistical testing, or literature writing. It creates structured frameworks for testing ideas.
